Artificial intelligence has gotten so good at mimicking human cognition that it can be jarring when it doesn’t quite work.
... When autofill presents the wrong words in a text. When Spotify pulls up a dud of a song Sometimes AI gets it very wrong.
But why do those glitches happen? And how are machines getting better and better at doing what our brains do?
To understand how AI works, you have to understand how human cognition works and recognize all of the processes we take for granted.
We don't think of the brain as mechanical. But cognition that seems to happen in an instant is actually a series of steps. That’s a lot like how an algorithm works.
In this interactive, we're slowing down the cognitive process to show you, step by step, how our brains work.

text.value: Artificial intelligence is transforming the world: how we travel, how we communicate, and how we live. But the AI researchers building these tools aren’t working from scratch. These capabilities take inspiration from how brains learn.
Click here to see how…

btn.text: How facial recognition knows who you are
How Spotify builds the perfect playlist

text.value: Almost half of your brain is devoted to the visual system. Computer vision, the area of AI that deals with how machines see the world, is attracting a lot of interest from researchers and the public. Face recognition programs, used for everything from law enforcement to unlocking phones, are attracting funding and controversy. To understand how they work, you first need to understand how we see faces.

In one-fifth of a second, your brain can decide whether a photo shows a face or some other object. We have neurons in our visual cortex dedicated just to faces, aptly called face cells. They register different features and the spatial relationship between them.

btn.text: What we see in a face

text.value: Usually you can recognize a face in fractions of a second. Take away a feature and it’s much harder. That’s because, to your brain, a face is not a single object, but a combination of features. The most important landmarks seem to be the eyes, mouth, and -- surprisingly -- eyebrows.
Can you recognize this face without eyebrows?
Here’s the same person’s face, but with no features removed.
Now can you guess who this is?

Most objects are harder to recognize when they are seen upside-down, but faces are especially difficult. Because those landmarks are not where face cells expect them to be, it may be that other parts of the visual cortex have to become involved. We eventually get it, but it takes longer.
Can you guess who is this?
Here’s the same person’s face, but oriented the way we’re used to seeing it.
Now can you guess who this is?

Shown an upside-down photo of Tom Cruise, AI draws a blank. One of Kim Kardashian confuses the system so much, it thinks it’s looking at Ozzy Osbourne. It’s unclear why the AI is wrong, but it is likely the system was never trained on upside-down portraits and can’t generalize.

Face recognition software relies on learning the parts of a face and the distance between them. People can recognize about 5,000 faces. AI can learn millions and identify them in moments. But these systems have plenty of weaknesses that our brains don’t. It might take a person a beat longer to recognize Kim Kardashian without eyebrows, but the AI is only about 35 percent sure it's her.

visual.title: AI and racial profiling of faces
visual.caption: Members of Congress misidentified by Amazon’s Rekognition software (clockwise from top left): Rep. John Lewis, Rep. Luis V. Gutiérrez, Rep. Bobby Rush, Sen. Edward J. Markey.

text.value: Some AI errors could have damaging consequences. AI software has been shown to make more mistakes identifying dark-skinned people, especially women. This is largely because the algorithm was trained on a lot of photos of white men. In a test by the ACLU, Amazon’s face recognition software falsely matched photos of 28 members of Congress with mug shots. 11 of those false matches -- almost 40% -- were non-white representatives, while Americans of color make up only 20% of Congress. Because of kinks in the technology and social biases built into the datasets, many activists don’t think facial recognition is ready for widespread use.

btn.text: How face recognition is being used

visual.title: You’ve been spotted
visual.caption: A demonstration of NEC's video face recognition technology.

text.value: Cities around the country are passing laws to protect privacy and regulate how agencies, including police, can use face recognition software. But places like stadiums and airports are unregulated. They’re rolling out the technology, arguing it will keep people safe and make lines faster.

A few years ago, the London police department created a team made up of super-recognizers: people who can recognize thousands of faces, often after one glimpse or years later. In 2016, the group made about 2,500 positive identifications in criminal cases. It’s not clear what gives these individuals extra face-recognizing power. Research hasn’t found any structural differences in their brains. This skill may be just an extreme case of being wired to recognize faces. One study found that pairing a super recognizer with AI gets better results than either on their own, or even having two people working together. These findings suggest humans and AI approach face recognition a little differently, with separate strengths and weaknesses that can be combined for powerful abilities.
When we listen to someone speak, our brains make educated guesses about what’s coming next. Artificial intelligence uses a similar process to predict what words you’ll text next on your phone.

speech.title: This word could save your life

text.value: For our ancestors to adapt and survive, our brains had to establish the relationships between sensory events, like the sounds of speech. Correctly guessing what comes next could save precious seconds in life-or-death situations. To do that, specific neurons in our auditory cortex respond to different phonemes, the smallest units of sound that distinguish one word from another. In English, there are 44 phonemes, like “w” and “f” and “t.”
It’s hard to pick the “right” word without context.
Those groups of neurons learn the relationships between different sounds, and the possibility that they go together, to predict what might come next.
What word comes next?

AI that predicts text also relies on understanding relationships. Consider the iPhone function that provides the next word in the messaging app, or Gmail’s new Smart Compose, which tries to guess what you are writing in an email. These AIs learn the correlations among letters, words, and sentences through training on millions of documents.

btn.text: Next: When AI gets it wrong

speech.title: How AI learns the worst from us

text.value: The problem with training AI on old documents is that it learns human biases. Google Translate used to turn the Turkish phrase “O bir doktor” into “He is a doctor,” though “o” isa gender-neutral third-person pronoun. Why? The algorithm saw more examples of doctors being identified as men and learned that relationship. Google now offers up both a “he” and “she” translation.

More brain research might help people with dyslexia who struggle to read at speed and are missing the ability to predict what comes next. Already, AI-assisted tools like Grammarly are helping people with dyslexia fix spelling errors.

A cutting-edge language model, GPT-2, can write full paragraphs and stories after getting a short prompt. Some of the text it creates can be a little wonky, but plenty of it reads like a person wrote it. It's convincing enough that its creators aren’t releasing all the details behind the technology, because of concerns that it could be used to automate trolling or fake news creation. For the time being, those are still the realm of human writers.[a]

We pair music with the most important events in our lives: hummed lullabies, war drums, wedding hymns, funeral dirges. But what makes a song feel right for a moment or mood? Our brains rely on responses and preferences, learned over time, to pick the perfect song. Spotify and other AI-driven music services start with similar methods but add a whole lot more to build customized playlists.

Our auditory cortex responds selectively to music-like sounds, but not to speech or non-musical noises. It’s still unclear whether other brain regions are involved in music processing and when these systems develop. But it’s clear that our brains are hard-wired to make sense of music.

music.title: Are my sad songs sadder than yours?

text.value: How we perceive music is part cultural and part universal, at least according to one study. Researchers had members of the Mafa, a Cameroon tribe with no exposure to Western culture, listen to pop songs. Most of the Mafa correctly labeled the songs happy, sad, or fearful, though their rates of accuracy were about 30 or 40 percent off compared to Western participants.

music.title: If you’re happy and you know it...

text.value: Drag the slider to show where this music falls on a scale from happiest to saddest?

You may sense how happy a song is, even if you haven’t heard it before, but AI has to be taught. The happiness — or lack thereof — of a piece of music is measured with a metric called valence. Songs with high valence, above 0.5, sound happier, while tracks below that sound sadder. Spotify had music experts teach an AI the valence of some songs. That algorithm was applied to the other songs on the platform. The rules are a secret sauce, but we do know they are fine-tuned regularly.
Here’s how your answers compared to Spotify’s valence measurements.

music.title: An AI playlist just for you

text.value: To put together a Discover Weekly playlist, a unique set of songs that you haven’t heard but might enjoy, Spotify relies on three recommendation models (with some extra rules they hard code, like no Christmas music after December 25). One model looks at the raw audio for data points like valence, but also the time signature, what key it is in, the tempo, and danceability. Spotify rates a song’s danceability based on factors including tempo, rhythm stability, beat strength, and overall regularity.
Where does this music fall on a scale from least to most danceable?
Here’s how your answers compared to Spotify’s valence measurements.

Another Spotify metric compares your listening history to other users. If you and a friend have similar tastes, perhaps you’ll like a new song your friend jams to. The final tool looks at text about the song on the internet, including news articles and blogs. This gives Spotify another way to see if two pieces of music are similar and might go well together. A non-algorithmic consideration? Playlists put together by everyone from casual listeners to professionals hired by Spotify.
Why AI sometimes gets it wrong

music.title: The right data, the wrong song

text.value: Even with all this data, the Spotify recommendation engine sometimes offers you a song you hate. Spotify’s approach relies on technical elements, while things that matter to listeners, like context, aren’t considered, says Valerio Velardo, CEO of AI music company Melodrive. “You can't expect to have a perfect friend to suggest perfect music for you all the time,” Velardo says, “and you can't expect the recommendation systems to do it either."

Music leaves an impression on the brain. According to recent research, the part of the brain that responds to music remains active in patients with Alzheimer’s. Music that was meaningful to a person can even pull him or her out of the haze for a short while. Music moves us through time, bringing memories into vivid relief.
